item.title: A Movie About America Broke My Heart
item.description: I am not a Shaker. That didn’t stop me from tearing up at “The Testament of Ann Lee.”

item.title: The Secret History of the Deep State
item.description: Seven pages of grand jury testimony from Richard Nixon were deemed so incendiary that they were hidden from the public for years.

item.title: It’s the A.I. Economy, Stupid
item.description: The Democratic Party needs to prepare for the coming tech revolution.

item.title: The Aftermath of Feeding America’s Credibility Into the Woodchipper
item.description: The brutality of U.S.A.I.D.’s closure and the disregard for the human toll betrayed a vision of a crueler, meaner, more insular world.

item.title: Ultraprocessed, Industrial Food Is Fine
item.description: They were at a much higher risk of malnutrition and missed out on the joy of a fresh Sumo orange in February.

item.title: What if the Valedictorians in America’s Schools Were the Cool Kids?
item.description: Lessons for America from Asia.

item.title: It’s Quieter Now. People Are Afraid.
item.description: Queens echoes with a quiet carved out by mass deportation.

item.title: This Is Just Who Trump Is
item.description: The birther of a nation.

item.title: Trump’s Obama Derangement Syndrome
item.description: The president shows, once again, that he shouldn’t be anywhere near the Oval.

item.title: Peter Attia, the Epstein Files and the Lie Propping Up Big Wellness
item.description: Health influencers sell themselves as iconoclasts, but many have cozy, uncritical relationships with the rich and powerful.

item.title: Now We Know What All Those People Got From Epstein
item.description: He knew how to give self-important people what they thought they deserved.

item.title: The Real Threat Isn’t Trump. It’s the MAGA Apparatus.
item.description: The round table convenes to debate whether we need to worry about the midterms being free and fair.

item.title: The President’s Personal Spy Chief
item.description: From joining an F.B.I. search of an election center to allegedly suppressing a whistleblower complaint, Tulsi Gabbard, the director of national intelligence, is eroding the independence of our intelligence community, argues Times Opinion’s editor, Kathleen Kingsbury.

item.title: A Simple Fix to Curb Federal Power
item.description: On “The Opinions,” the columnist David French explains how federal immunity makes it nearly impossible to sue over civil rights violations — and why a simple change to the law could finally hold agencies like ICE accountable.

item.title: Are We Giving Trump Too Much Credit?
item.description: We obsess over what Trump and MAGA want, the columnist Jamelle Bouie says, but why do we assume they’re the only forces with agency? He discusses with Michelle Cottle and David French on “The Opinions.”

item.title: They Used to Rule the West. Now They’re Dying.
item.description: The decline of traditional political parties is the precondition for our hyperpolitical age.

item.title: How Hard Is It to Rig an American Election, Really?
item.description: The round table convenes to debate whether we need to worry about the midterms being free and fair.

item.title: The Finance Industry Is a Grift. Let’s Start Treating It That Way.
item.description: Regulating the industry is useful. Shaming it is crucial.

item.title: America’s Rare-Earths Solution Is Hiding in Plain Sight
item.description: The real threat to a secure and sustainable supply of rare earths is not that they are scarce, but that so much is wasted.

item.title: Trump’s Indecent Nuclear Proposal
item.description: The president’s new plan is aspirational at best and, at worst, disingenuous.

item.title: At These Olympic Games, Team U.S.A. Is Not Team White House
item.description: Although the actions of those in power have filled me with sadness, I love the people of this country.

item.title: The Culture War Is Over. Bad Bunny Won.
item.description: American pop culture is global pop culture, and vice versa.

item.title: The Globalization of Canadian Rage
item.description: The world is angry. Canada’s been there all along.

item.title: I Was Arrested for Doing My Job as a Reporter. Who’s Next?
item.description: I covered a Minnesota church protest. Press credentials didn’t protect me.

item.title: We Didn’t Ask for This Internet
item.description: Cory Doctorow and Tim Wu explain why the internet failed to live up to its early promise.

item.title: I’m the Prime Minister of Spain. This Is Why the West Needs Migrants.
item.description: In Spain, it is our duty to become the welcoming and tolerant society our ancestors would have hoped to find on the other side of our borders.

item.title: Fighting Threats to Free and Fair Elections
item.description: Readers add their own suggestions in response to an editorial about ways to defend the election system. Also: President Trump’s racist post about the Obamas.

item.title: An Elegy for My Washington Post
item.description: Seven governing principles still hang in the newsroom, but now more as reproach than reminder.

item.title: Melania Is the ‘Only Immigrant Trump Likes’
item.description: “Here is Melania, the only immigrant Trump likes, in her satin-lined cage. It’s an incredibly unpleasant juxtaposition,” the columnist Maureen Dowd says about the film “Melania” on “The Opinions.” The movie debuted as ICE raids rippled through places like Minneapolis.

item.title: The Empty Propaganda of ‘Melania’
item.description: President Trump is a master of creating false realities, and the new “Melania” film reveals that the first lady is too, Maureen Dowd, an opinion columnist, argues on “The Opinions.” She and her fellow columnist Carlos Lozada unpack how the documentary serves as a piece of propaganda.

item.title: ‘The Mistake of Feminism’
item.description: Is it possible to support women while also opposing abortion? The pro-life activist Lila Rose argues yes. The key, she says, is to acknowledge that men and women are inherently different.

item.title: Who Decides When a Pregnancy Is Life-Threatening?
item.description: Strict abortion bans can be at odds with emergency medical care. The pro-life activist Lila Rose argues they can coexist.

item.title: A Law That Might Just Save the Midterms
item.description: President Trump has made it clear that he is set to accept only one outcome of the midterms: MAGA wins.

item.title: Hollywood Viewed Them as Maids. The Randolph Sisters’ Talent Shone Through.
item.description: Watching the dazzling Randolph sisters now offers important lessons — and delightful entertainment.

item.title: Trump Brings Out the Worst in Everyone
item.description: Us included.

item.title: A Gilded Age Illusion: What ‘Melania’ Is Really Selling
item.description: The columnists decode ‘Melania’ — the film and the person.

item.title: ICE’s ‘Reckless, Xenophobic Mission’
item.description: Readers suggest steps to take in response to federal actions that have terrorized some communities. Also: When the president is rude; imperfect marriages.

item.title: It’s Not the Cartels That Worry Claudia Sheinbaum
item.description: Trump wants total war on Mexico’s cartels. Sheinbaum won’t give it to him.

item.title: What’s Really Driving These Bogus Claims of Voter Fraud
item.description: Mr. Trump’s recent justification for unconstitutionally nationalizing elections is false, illegal and dangerous to democracy.

item.title: ‘Melania’: Watching a First Lady Vanish in Plain Sight
item.description: Glamour, silence and a very big hat.

item.title: Why Ending Roe Wasn’t Enough for the Pro-Life Movement
item.description: Activists won the legal battle. Are they losing the culture war?

item.title: ICE’s Surveillance State Isn’t Tracking Only Immigrants
item.description: The nationwide nativist dragnet has a long list of targets.

item.title: This Is the Real Reason Susie Wiles Talked to Me 11 Times
item.description: What did her unguarded remarks reveal about the Trump White House?

item.title: Erasing American History, the Trump Way
item.description: Readers object to the National Park Service’s deletions at historic sites ordered by the Trump administration. Also: David Brooks’s farewell column.
